channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: At Front Lines of Armenia-Azerbaijan Fighting, Death and Fear Reign
item.description: Times journalists find civilians huddling in basements as a three-week-old conflict over the disputed Caucasus territory hints of a long and punishing fight.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents taking shelter in the basement of an apartment building in Stepanakert, in Nagorno-Karabakh.

item.title: ‘We Have to Speak Out’: Thai Students Defy Protest Ban
item.description: Armed with umbrellas, social media and global support, young Thais are taking on a government that has used arrests, legal intimidation and water cannons to try to stop them.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of anti-government protesters rallied at Victory Monument in Bangkok on Sunday.

item.title: In Election, Bolivia Faces the Legacy of Ousted President Evo Morales
item.description: Sunday’s election is seen as a referendum on Evo Morales, who lifted many out of poverty in his 14 years as president, but whose policies and tone divided the country.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: A polling site in Achocalla, Bolivia, on Sunday. The election is widely viewed as a referendum on the 14-year political project of former President Evo Morales.

item.title: A Storied Female Warlord Surrenders, Taliban Say, Exposing Afghan Weakness
item.description: She was undefeated in decades of war, but her decision was an act of survival. A government that has come to depend on unreliable militias finds itself vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Najim Rahim and Fatima Faizi
item.media:description: Bibi Ayesha, an Afghan warlord, at her home in Nahrin district, Baghlan Province, Afghanistan, last month.

item.title: Using a Law It Hates, Far Right in Spain Takes Aim at Franco’s Rivals
item.description: Vox, an ultranationalist party in Madrid, is working to remove memorials to Socialist figures of the 1930s, calling the effort a warning that a “law of historical memory” should be abolished.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Emilio Naranjo/EFE, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Spanish government used the “law of historical memory” to exhume the remains of Gen. Francisco Franco, the former dictator, from a mausoleum near Madrid last October.

item.title: For Young Rohingya Brides, Marriage Means a Perilous, Deadly Crossing
item.description: Girls and young women from refugee camps in Bangladesh, promised to men they have never met, are undertaking the dangerous journey to Malaysia to join them.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: After months at sea, hundreds of ethnic Rohingya refugees, most of them women and girls, landed in the Indonesian province of Aceh in September.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern's Party Scores a Landslide Win in New Zealand Elections
item.description: New Zealand’s prime minister and her party are coasting to victory in national elections, though it is unclear how far she will push her progressive promises.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand claimed victory in Auckland on Saturday.

item.title: Man Beheads Teacher on the Street in France and Is Killed by Police
item.description: The victim was immediately depicted as a martyr to freedom of expression. France’s antiterrorism prosecutors are investigating the attack, which took place in a suburb north of Paris.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Police officers near the scene north of Paris where a man decapitated a schoolteacher.

item.title: Armenia and Azerbaijan Reach New Cease-Fire for Nagorno-Karabakh, Then Report Violations
item.description: A truce brokered just a week earlier failed to hold. The war between the two Caucasus countries has already killed hundreds.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Devastation on Saturday in Stepanakert, the capital of the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh.

item.title: Bill Offering L.G.B.T. Protections in Italy Spurs Rallies on Both Sides
item.description: Supporters frame the measure as a long-overdue means to provide basic human rights. Opponents depict it as an overreaching step that would suppress opinion.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A demonstration against the bill at Piazza del Popolo in Rome.

item.title: Who Was ‘El Padrino,’ Godfather to Drug Cartel? Mexico’s Defense Chief, U.S. Says
item.description: Drug enforcement agents had long tried to solve the mystery of “El Padrino,” a shadowy, powerful force. They’ve now identified him as Salvador Cienfuegos, Mexico’s defense chief from 2012 to 2018.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Gen. Salvador Cienfuegos of Mexico saluting soldiers at a military camp in Mexico City in 2016. He was arrested in Los Angeles on money laundering and drug trafficking charges.

item.title: Israeli Charity Treats Ultra-Orthodox Virus Patients at Home
item.description: Health experts say the treatment offered by a religious charity is a gamble. It has also fed concern about the community’s acting with increasing autonomy in an already divided nation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: A volunteer with Hasdei Amram, a religious charity, leaving after a home visit to a coronavirus patient in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: The Beirut Blast Shattered Her Masterpieces. Now, the Rebuilding Starts.
item.description: Over three decades as Lebanon’s premier stained-glass artist, Maya Husseini advanced a fragile medium in a country prone to violent shocks. Then came the big one.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maya Husseini at her studio in Beirut. “Thirty years of my professional life were gone,” she said of the blast that rocked the city’s port in August.

item.title: Thailand Steps Up Response as Antigovernment Protests Escalate
item.description: Water cannons were used for the first time to clear protesters off the streets, and two demonstrators face charges that could put them in prison for life.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protestors and the police clashed in Bangkok on Friday.

item.title: Putin Proposes Extending U.S.-Russia Nuclear Treaty for a Year
item.description: With negotiations for a five-year extension stalled, the Russian president’s proposal puts pressure on President Trump to salvage an Obama-era accord.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin, who works from home these days, spoke with the Russian Security Council by video link on Friday.

item.title: In Hong Kong, Communist Party Officials Stride Out of the Shadows
item.description: The growing power and profile of the Chinese government’s liaison office has brought the party’s playbook into the open.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy, Vivian Wang and Chris Buckley
item.category: Liaison Office of the Central People's Government (Hong Kong)
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Liaison Office of the Central People’s Government in Hong Kong has taken a more overt role in the affairs of the semiautonomous city.

item.title: With Brexit Clock Ticking, Boris Johnson Vows, Again, to Walk Away
item.description: The prime minister blew up over what he called Europe’s insistence that Britain make all the compromises. But Europe says it still wants to talk.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson called off Brexit negotiations on Friday.

item.title: Killing of White Farmer Becomes a Flash Point in South Africa
item.description: Outside a court hearing for two Black suspects in a murder case, white Afrikaners nostalgic for the apartheid era and Black protesters angry that whites still own most farmland squared off.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Monica Mark
item.media:description: Protesting farmers kneel in prayer in Senekal, South Africa, where two Black men accused of killing a young white farmer appeared in court on Friday.

item.title: This Ex-Taliban Commander Is Now the Face of Afghan Security
item.description: Rahmatullah Andar once fought the government and then turned against the Taliban. Now he is a prominent spokesman, and his story is an example of the long war’s many plot twists.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Najim Rahim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rahmatullah Andar, once a feared Taliban commander, is now spokesman for the National Security Council of the American-backed government of Afghanistan.

item.title: Retired French Surgeon Faces 312 Pedophilia and Abuse Charges
item.description: Prosecutors said the rapes and sexual assaults took place at several hospitals over three decades, and were documented in a diary. Most of the accusers were 15 or younger.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Lawyers in a courtroom in Saintes, France, in March, at a hearing for Joël Le Scouarnec on previous charges. Mr. Le Scouarnec faces hundreds of new charges stemming from that case.

item.title: China Threatens to Detain Americans if U.S. Prosecutes Chinese Scholars
item.description: American officials said China had insisted that the Justice Department not proceed with cases against the arrested scholars, who are in the Chinese military and face charges of visa fraud.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Western officials and human rights advocates have said for years that the Chinese police and other security agencies engage in arbitrary detentions.

item.title: After Fleeing Poland, an Antiracism Activist Finds Refuge in Norway
item.description: A decision to grant asylum on political grounds highlights growing concerns over democratic backsliding in Poland.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Monika Pronczuk and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Rafal Gawel in his office in Warsaw in 2017.

item.title: Refugees Who Assisted U.S. Military Denied Entry Into U.S.
item.description: President Trump has reduced the flow of refugees into the country to a trickle, and even Iraqis and Afghans who risked their lives for American service members have been cut off.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Afghan refugees in Turkey in February. Last year, the Trump administration reduced the overall cap on refugee admissions and empowered local governments to block resettlement in their communities.

item.title: Indonesian ex-pilot, convicted in midair poison plot, is reported dead from Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat
item.media:description: Pollycarpus Budihari Priyanto in a court room in Jakarta, Indonesia, in 2007.

item.title: Doctors find signs of recovery in some Covid-19 patients with severe lung damage.
item.dc:creator: Lina Zeldovich
item.media:description: An X-ray of a Texas Covid-19 patient’s lungs. While doctors have worried that lung damage from the disease might be permanent, patients in some studies have shown signs of recovery.

item.title: ‘It’s insane’: This is what happened when schools reopened in a virus-hit community.
item.dc:creator: Kate Taylor
item.media:credit: Lindsay D'Addato for The New York Times
item.media:description: Corner Canyon High School in Utah. A coronavirus outbreak forced the school to close shortly after opening for the fall.

item.title: Pandemic weariness is making it harder to stem outbreaks, health officials say.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Sarah Mervosh and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Medical workers treating coronavirus patients at a hospital in Slany, Czech Republic, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump’s Sanctions on International Court May Do Little Beyond Alienating Allies
item.description: Critics say the administration has targeted a human rights lawyer with economic penalties meant for warlords, dictators and authoritarian governments.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. records over 70,000 cases in one day for the first time since July.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in Lucas County, Ohio.

item.title: Suspect Stalked French School Before Beheading Teacher, Officials Say
item.description: The suspect, a Russian immigrant, was angered by a classroom display of caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad and sought help identifying the teacher involved.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Flowers outside the Collège du Bois d’Aulne middle school as part of a memorial to the teacher who was killed in Eragny, a suburb of Paris, on Friday.

item.title: Will we remember how hugging works when we are allowed to do it again?
item.dc:creator: A.C. Shilton
item.media:description: Michelle Grant (R) hugs her mother, Mary Grace Sileo through a plastic drop cloth during Memorial Day Weekend.

item.title: Turkey Moves Closer to Activating Its Russian Air Defense System
item.description: With the firing of a test missile, Turkey appeared to ignore an agreement with the Trump administration to delay putting the S-400 system into operation.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: The S-400 air defense system, purchased from Russia, at an air base in Ankara in November 2019.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Halloween in America looks extra terrifying this year.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Eitan Haber, Rabin Aide and Israeli Wordsmith, Dies at 80
item.description: Mr. Haber moved between journalism and service to the prime minister whose death he announced to the nation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Eitan Haber read lyrics from the anthem “Song of Peace” at Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin’s funeral in 1995. The sheet of paper had been retrieved from Mr. Rabin’s pocket after he was shot by an assassin at a peace rally.

item.title: He Dismembered His Boss, but a Judge Ruled It Manslaughter
item.description: A New York Times reporter and true crime author reflects on one of the strangest crimes that he’s encountered in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Vancouver mansion where Yuan Gang was killed by Zhao Li in 2015.

item.title: Netherlands to Allow Doctors to Help End Lives of Terminally Ill Children
item.description: Hugo de Jonge, the Dutch health minister, said that “incurably ill” children ages 1 to 12 should be able to die with the help of a doctor.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Claire Moses
item.media:description: “In a small number of cases, palliative care isn’t sufficient,” Hugo de Jonge, the Dutch health minister, wrote in a recent letter to the parliament.

item.title: Detention of Government Critic in Poland Raises Fears of a Crackdown
item.description: Roman Giertych, who has been involved in high-profile cases against members of the governing party, was put in handcuffs and had his home searched by the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Marc Santora
item.media:description: The Polish Bar Council expressed its “greatest concern” over the detention of Roman Giertych, a lawyer.

item.title: Ex-French President Sarkozy Faces New Charge in Campaign Finance Case
item.description: Prosecutors added a charge of criminal conspiracy to a long-running investigation into whether his 2007 campaign received illegal Libyan financing.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The former French president Nicolas Sarkozy, shown in June, was charged Friday with criminal conspiracy by financial prosecutors.

item.title: The federal deficit balloons to a record $3.1 trillion, even as the pain for jobless workers sharpens.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Emily Badger and Quoctrung Bui

item.title: Turning the Lights Down on the At War Channel
item.description: The Times project that has provided original reporting and firsthand accounts of conflict is winding down.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Katzenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Pfc. Paul Landenberger, a soldier in Viper Company, on patrol in the Korengal Valley in April 2009.

item.title: Canadian Military's Wolf Exercise Alarms Nova Scotians
item.description: They also mounted speakers that broadcast growling in the woods of Nova Scotia. It was all part of a psychological training exercise.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: C. Dani & I. Jeske/De Agostini Picture Library, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A fake letter warning of wolf sightings in Nova Scotia caused widespread alarm.

item.title: Its most famous coach has the virus, but college football rolls on.
item.media:credit: Gary Cosby Jr/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Alabama Coach Nick Saban’s coronavirus infection came amid several outbreaks on campuses.

item.title: Indonesia overtakes the Philippines as the hardest-hit country in Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat
item.media:description: Disinfecting a house in Jakarta, Indonesia, last week.

item.title: A Sharply Split Screen
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times; Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in Miami and Joe Biden in Philadelphia during simultaneous town hall events.

item.title: A Chinese city says it has given some residents a vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: A laboratory of the Chinese vaccine maker Sinovac Biotech during a government-organized media tour in Beijing in September.

item.title: Trump and Biden offer starkly different views of the pandemic during dueling events.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: President Trump spoke at a forum in Miami on Thursday.

item.title: Faced with twin crises, Britain’s leader is stalling for time.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson in London this week.

item.title: Trump supports a bigger relief bill, but a deal is far from certain.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Erin Scott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The $1.8 trillion package that Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has proposed has proven to be a non-starter with Senate Republicans, making President Trump’s call for a bigger bill a complication.

item.title: In One of the World’s Longest Lockdowns, One Man is Omnipresent
item.description: Daniel Andrews, Victoria’s premier, has conducted 100 consecutive daily news conferences. In Melbourne, we all watch. We are all exhausted.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell
item.media:description: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews speaks during question time at the Victoria State Parliament last month.

item.title: Salvador Cienfuegos Zepeda, Mexico's Ex-Defense Minister, Is Arrested in L.A.
item.description: Gen. Salvador Cienfuegos Zepeda, who was detained at the airport, is the first high-ranking Mexican military official to be taken into custody in the U.S. in connection with drug-related corruption.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed
item.media:description: Gen. Salvador Cienfuegos Zepeda speaking at a reception in Mexico City in 2014.

item.title: Will Jacinda Ardern Win a Second Term? New Zealand’s Election, Explained
item.description: Voters go to the polls on Saturday after a campaign that focused heavily on Ms. Ardern’s successful handling of the coronavirus outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand during the final day of election campaigning in Auckland on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Election, Boris Johnson, Coronavirus: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The French president, Emmanuel Macron, on Wednesday announced a curfew for Paris and eight other major cities

item.title: Remdesivir Fails to Prevent Covid-19 Deaths in Huge Trial
item.description: Critics said the study, sponsored by the W.H.O., was too poorly conducted to be definitive.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu and Gina Kolata
item.media:description: A study by the World Health Organization found that remdesivir did not reduce deaths in a large group of patients. “This puts the issue to rest,” one scientist said.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The White House is embracing a dubious route to “herd immunity,” a strategy rejected by most health experts.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Major Retailers in Britain Say No to Glitter for Christmas
item.description: Morrisons, John Lewis and Waitrose said they would not be using glitter in their holiday products this year. Does that really help the environment?
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin

item.title: Separatists Kill 14 in Attack on Oil Convoy in Pakistan's Baluchistan Province
item.description: The assault was an escalation of violence in the resource-rich province of Baluchistan, which has become a nexus of Chinese development projects and heavy security crackdowns.
item.dc:creator: Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Bodies of the victims of the attack in Baluchistan arriving in Karachi on Friday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Europe’s restrictions, India’s smog, U.S. voters: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Carole Landry
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The Soho area of London on Thursday. Matt Hancock, the British health secretary, announced tightened virus restrictions for the city and other areas of England.

item.title: Cyprus Ends ‘Golden Passport’ Program After Corruption Accusations
item.description: An investigation into an initiative that grants citizenship to wealthy foreign investors appeared to show lawmakers helping to arrange a passport for a businessman despite being told he was a convicted criminal.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The city of Limassol, Cyprus. Under the passport program, foreigners who invest at least 2 million euros in the country can apply for a Cypriot passport.

item.title: As Coronavirus Surges and Brexit Deadline Nears, Boris Johnson Stalls
item.description: The prime minister’s delaying strategy carries severe risks if he misplays his hand, with the pandemic worsening and a Brexit deadline approaching.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and Rishi Sunak, the finance chief, leaving 10 Downing Street for a cabinet meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: How United Airlines Is Trying to Plan Around a Pandemic
item.description: The airline has to figure out which planes to stash in the desert and which ones to park at airports without knowing when demand will recover.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Lucy Hewett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A United Airlines plane undergoes inspection at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago before it is cleared for flight. The airline is trying to predict where travelers will fly, a challenge in the best of times.

item.title: In India, doctors warn that deteriorating air quality could make Covid-19 even worse.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: An aerial view shows the city engulfed in heavy smog in outskirts of New Delhi, India.

item.title: Will a Half-Step by Macron Be Enough to Blunt France’s Second Wave?
item.description: The imposition of a curfew in several major cities underscored a difficult choice: further dampening the economy or risking more lives.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: An interview with President Emmanuel Macron of France played on a TV in a closed bar in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Freshman enrollment drops significantly at U.S. universities and community colleges.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:description: Incoming freshmen participate in the “Tiger Walk” at the University of Missouri.

item.title: Trump’s Tweets on Troop Withdrawals Unnerve Pentagon
item.description: The president’s demands to draw down forces in Afghanistan, Somalia and Syria seek to fulfill a campaign promise. But officials warn rapid troop reductions could bolster adversaries.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers in Hasakah Province in northeastern Syria this month. President Trump’s comments on troop presence in the country have conflicted with the Pentagon’s decision to send additional forces there.
